Posts.Content: Hi ladies. I was wondering if anyone had DIEP (delayed) and how recovery was? How long until you could do work from home? Were you happy with your results? It's getting close to my op, they've said September, and I will be having it done at Royal Marsden Chelsea, by an amazing surgeon, hence I have had to wait an eternity. I feel very nervous though and sometimes I ask myself if it's worth putting myself through so much again! Caroline x
Posts.Title: DIEP recon ladies

Posts.Content: Great, I will. Thank you Helen!
Posts.Title: DIEP recon ladies

Posts.Content: Approaching the end of treatment. Last two herceptins are next month. Feeling a bit weird, but at the same time relief I guess. I have been super annoyed the whole way through having this extra time added on to treatment, I am aware that I am lucky to have it but envy those who didn't. How did everyone else feel at the end of active treatment? Caroline x
Posts.Title: All my treatment nearly finished, weird feeling.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all your responses lovely ladies.   I suppose overall I am please I am at the end. 15 months out of my life is enough. I have more surgery to come but I see that as a positive exerpeince and not part of treatment. x
Posts.Title: All my treatment nearly finished, weird feeling.

Posts.Content: Whoops I guess I didn't think of that haha great news Sue love hearing stories like yours! Does the worry go away?
Posts.Title: Breast cancer remission and 5 year plus survivors

Posts.Content: it's all very positive indeed, thanks for sharing Gaz! Caroline
Posts.Title: Breast cancer remission and 5 year plus survivors

Posts.Content: Are there any node positive breast cancer survivors around 5 years plus NED? Or do you know anyone who is? Would be interested in hearing your story, just for some positive thinking  this morning really. x
Posts.Title: Breast cancer remission and 5 year plus survivors

Posts.Content: Hi Gill.  Sorry to hear about your dx.  I thought I'd give you a bit of suppprt as I'm a year on from chemo now. Firstly  chemo is administered through a cannula. It doesn't hurt too much but if you don't like needles make it clear you want a picc line. They fit one in top of your arm and then you don't have to worry about cannula. I didn't have one so can't give you much advice but if you search picc line on the Macmillan website it'll tell you more. Cold cap is not pleasant but worth trying   I tried it and lost all my hair and it wasn't that bad. I embraced it in the end everyone thinks it's the worst part of chemo in the beginning but for most it doesn't phase you too much. I wish you well and it goes so quickly you will soon be where I am wondering where that last year went. Caroline x
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Grade 3 Ductal Carcinoma non Lymph

Posts.Content: Here is my dog Lucky as a puppy. Shes 6 now.  She helped me through cancer, she's the best!!
Posts.Title: Dogs (man's best friends)

Posts.Content: Here's another pic of her with her Daddy
Posts.Title: Dogs (man's best friends)

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah. Sorry to hear about your diagnosis, on New Years Eve of all nights. I had FEC-T in July 2013. It is bearable. Generally people tolerate one chemo better than the other. I found FEC tough. It made me feel spaced out and out of it. T was bearable I just ached all over my body, but by the 3rd I had no side effects at all and it was a breeze. I didn't have triple negative cancer, but it seems that chemo works very well on triple neg cancers and now you have a treatment plan you should start feeling a little more in control. 18 months on, the key things I would tell others is to have as much support as possible. Don't be too proud to ask for help, oh and hope. Hope is what kept me going. Good luck with it, you can do it. x
